title: Microscopy Analysis and Mechanical Properties of PETG-CF
content: 3D printing is constantly evolving for different engineering fields for the purpose or opportunity to obtain a variety of mechanical properties [1]. This technique allows the deposition of layers and/or structures on top of each other, which have been shown to have potential in industrial applications [2]. Studies in the literature show that the mechanical properties are related to the type of layer and/or structures obtained by additive manufacturing [3]. On the other hand, the types of layers and/or structures obtained by PETG-FC currently has an innovative field due to its attributes, therefore generating research on these printed materials is of great interest for the aeronautical, aerospace and automotive industry [4, 5]. Also, the type of deposition of PETG-FC composite layers and/or structures by fused deposition modeling can have excellent mechanical property attributes for engineering use and biomedical area [6]. However, research on PETG-FC has not yet been fully completed [7]. Therefore, this study shows the effect of the type of structure of the material obtained with PETG-FC on the effect of the mechanical properties. In the present study, a PETG filament (85-90%) with carbon fiber (10-15%) with a diameter of 1.75 mm, purchased on the Internet, was used. The production of tensile, flexural and compression specimens with 10%, 70% and 100% infill percentages with a rectilinear internal infill pattern with a 45Â° print angle were modeled on a FlashForge Creator 3 pro printer. Table 1 describes the printing parameters for each specimen. ASTM D638-02 for tension, ASTM D695-02a for compression specimens and ASTM D790-03 for 3-point bending were used. The characterization of the specimens was carried out using a SHIMADZU universal testing machine with a capacity of 100 kN. Figure 1 shows the tensile, compression and flexural specimens fabricated with PETG/carbon fiber and the infill patterns used in each. The specimens were observed under a Mitutoyo microscope model TM-505B.
